content.text: Calculate the magnitude of the momentum of the disc
magnitude of momentum =   .........
State the magnitude of the impulse exerted on the disc and the direction, in degrees, of the impulse relative to the original direction of travel
direction of impulse:   .........  Â° to original direction
Determine the magnitude of the new momentum of the disc and its new direction relative to the original direction of travel by drawing a scale diagram

The hockey player strikes the disc with his hockey stick and the momentum of the disc changes. The disc gains momentum of \(3.0 \text{kg} \text{m / s}\) at \(45^{\circ}\) to the original direction of travel of the disc, as shown in Fig. 1.2
Fig. 1.1 shows an ice-hockey player moving on ice. He is preparing to hit the solid disc called a puck
The disc of mass \(0.16\mathrm{kg}\) is moving horizontally across the surface of the ice at a speed of \(15\mathrm{m / s}\)
Describe what happens to the velocity of the ball in the short period of time as it accelerates downwards uniformly
The ball reaches terminal velocity
Describe and explain the motion of the ball from when it is released until it reaches terminal velocity
Calculate the gravitational potential energy transferred from the ball as it falls
gravitational potential energy transferred = ....................................................
When the ball reaches the bottom of the tube, it has a speed of \(1.2 \text{m/s}\). Calculate the kinetic energy of the ball at the bottom of the tube
kinetic energy =   .........
Explain why the value calculated in (c)(i) is different from that calculated in (c)(ii)
The metal ball has a mass of \(2.1 \text{g}\). It falls a distance of \(0.80 \text{m}\) between being released and reaching the bottom of the tube
A vertical tube contains a liquid. A metal ball is held at rest by a thread just below the surface of the liquid, as shown in Fig. 2.1
The diameter of the tube is much greater than the diameter of the ball. The ball is released and it accelerates downwards uniformly for a short period of time
Calculate the pressure of the gas supply. Give your answer to 3 significant figures
pressure =   .........
The area of the piston in contact with the gas is \(0.025 \text{m}^2\)
Calculate the resultant force on the piston
resultant force =   .........
The pressure of the gas causes the piston to move a distance of \(0.50 \text{m}\) to the right
Calculate the work done by the gas from the supply on the piston
work done =   .........
Fig. 3.3 shows that the gas supply is now connected to a cylinder that contains a piston
The pressure of the gas moves the piston to the right
A U-shaped tube of constant cross-sectional area contains water of density \(1000 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\). Both sides of the U-tube are open to the atmosphere
Fig. 3.1 shows that the water levels in the two sides of the tube are equal
Fig. 3.1 Fig. 3.2
The atmospheric pressure is \(1.00 \times 10^{5} \text{ Pa}\)

The left-hand side of the tube is now connected to a gas supply using a length of rubber tubing. This causes the level of the water in the left-hand side of the tube to drop by \(0.200 \text{m}\), as shown in Fig. 3.2
Describe, in terms of molecules and their motion, how a liquid differs from a gas
Describe what happens to molecules of the liquid as its temperature begins to increase
Explain, in terms of molecules, why a supply of thermal energy is needed to change the liquid into a gas
The density of the liquid in the test-tube is \(0.86 \text{g} /\text{cm}^3\). The volume of liquid in the test-tube is \(50 \text{cm}^3\)
The liquid reaches its boiling point. It now absorbs \(18 000 \text{J}\) of thermal energy and all of the liquid changes into a gas
Calculate the specific latent heat of vaporisation of this liquid
specific latent heat =   .........

A large test-tube contains a liquid at room temperature. An electric heater is immersed in the liquid and is switched on. Thermal energy is supplied to the liquid by the heater. The temperature of the liquid increases until it reaches its boiling point. The liquid then starts to change into gas
The outside surface of the container gets hot. Some thermal energy passes through the metal because vibrating atoms in the metal collide with neighbouring atoms and transfer energy to them
Explain how the rest of the thermal energy is conducted through the metal container to the outside surface by another process
The outside surface of the container is brightly polished and shiny
Explain how this reduces the power that needs to be supplied to keep the oil at the correct temperature
The metal container is spherical. The spherical container has a smaller surface area than a long, thin container of the same volume
Explain the advantage of using a spherical container
A metal container is used to cook food. The metal container has thick walls. Hot cooking oil at a temperature of \(120^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\) is poured into the container
Explain why the direction of the wavefronts changes in the way shown in Fig. 6.1
Using information from Fig. 6.1, determine the frequency of the wave
frequency =   .........
Determine the speed of the wave in the right-hand side of the tank
The speed of the wave in the left-hand part of the tank is \(0.39 \text{m / s}\)
Fig. 6.1 shows a shallow tank viewed from above. The depth of the water is different in the two parts of the tank. Fig. 6.1 shows the crests and the troughs of a wave that pass from left to right
As the wave passes from one side to the other, the direction of the wavefronts changes
A permanent magnet is made from only one material
Underline the material from which it is possible to make a permanent magnet
aluminium copper soft iron mercury plastic steel uranium
Describe what is meant by the direction of a magnetic field. State the direction of the magnetic field between the two poles in Fig. 7.1
Describe and explain what happens to the beam of electrons in the magnetic field between the poles of the magnet in Fig. 7.1
An electron source produces a narrow beam of electrons that all travel at the same speed
The electron source is placed in a vacuum and the beam of electrons travels vertically downwards. Fig. 7.1 shows the beam of electrons before it passes between the N-pole and the S-pole of a magnet
A beam consists of \(\alpha\) -particles, \(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays
Explain how a uniform magnetic field may be used to separate the \(\alpha\) -particles, the \(\beta\) -particles and the \(\gamma\) -rays
Explain what is meant by electromotive force (e.m.f.)
Calculate the current in heating element \(\mathsf{R}_1\)
current =   .........
Calculate the power produced in heating element \(\mathsf{R}_1\)
The resistance of heating element \(\mathsf{R}_2\) is \(60\Omega\)
Switches \(\mathsf{S}_1\), \(\mathsf{S}_2\) and \(\mathsf{S}_3\) are closed
1. State and explain how the current in \(\mathsf{R}_2\) compares with the current in \(\mathsf{R}_1\)
An electric heater contains two heating elements \(\mathsf{R}_{1}\) and \(\mathsf{R}_{2}\). An electric motor operates a fan. The fan blows cool air over the heating elements
Fig. 8.1 shows the circuit
The heater is powered by a mains supply of e.m.f. 240V
Switches \(\mathsf{S}_1\) and \(\mathsf{S}_2\) are closed. Heating element \(\mathsf{R}_1\) gets hot. The resistance of \(\mathsf{R}_1\) is \(30\Omega\)
Describe what is observed during _total internal reflection_
State two conditions required for light to be totally internally reflected
Describe and explain the action of optical fibres in communication technology. You may draw a diagram in your answer
State what is meant by background radiation. Suggest one source for it
Deduce the type of radiation emitted by polonium-208. Explain your answer
Write down the nuclide equation for the decay of polonium-208
A sample containing atoms of the radioactive isotope polonium-208 is removed from a lead container and brought close to the detector. The average count rate increases to 890 counts/minute
When two sheets of paper are inserted between the sample and the detector, the average count rate returns to 40 counts/minute
Polonium-208 is represented by the symbol \(^{208}_{84}\mathrm{Po}\). It decays to an isotope of lead (Pb)
A radiation detector is placed on the bench in a laboratory. It detects a background count rate of 40 counts/minute
